results.name: Length of the period of the continued fraction of (1+sqrt(n))/2.
comment: First occurrence of n in this sequence see A146343.
Records see A146344.
Indices where records occurred see A146345.
a(n) =1 for n = 4 k^2 + 4 k + 5 (A078370). For primes see A005473.

link: R. J. Mathar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000.
formula: a(n) = 0 iff n is a square (A000290). - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Apr 11 2017
example: a(2) = 2 because continued fraction of (1+sqrt(2))/2 = 1, 4, 1, 4, 1, 4, 1, ... has period (1,4) length 2.
maple: A146326 := proc(n) if not issqr(n) then numtheory[cfrac]( (1+sqrt(n))/2, 'periodic','quotients') ; nops(%[2]) ; else 0 ; fi; end: seq(A146326(n),n=1..100) ; # _R. J. Mathar_, Sep 06 2009
mathematica: Table[cf = ContinuedFraction[(1 + Sqrt[n])/2]; If[Head[cf[[-1]]] === List, Length[cf[[-1]]], 0], {n, 100}]
f[n_] := Length@ ContinuedFraction[(1 + Sqrt[n])/2][[-1]]; Array[f, 100] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Apr 11 2017 *)
results.author: _Artur Jasinski_, Oct 30 2008
